review_blob: (#64) Bottle into tulip. Ar: Sweet with big hop aroma. Ap: Black darkness with a tan head that stays around thin. T: Sweet. Earthy. Chocolate. Nutty. Hoppy bitterness lingering on finish. P: Smooth, not a lot of carbonation. O: Its good, I dig the ABV. Might suggest it, but not sure if Id buy for myself again.

Flight @ beer shoppe. 3oz. Aroma: A little boozy on the aroma. Caramel, vanilla, brown sugar. Appearance: Darker amber. Copper in color. Taste: Med bodied. Caramel. More malty and vanilla. Some strong fruit flavors. Palate: A little fruity on palate. Lingering flavors of residual sugar. Overall: Tasty beer. Would suggest to someone wanting a good full-flavored red.

Flight @ beer shoppe. 3oz. Aroma: Pumpkin spice is there but not much. Some cinnamon aroma. Appearance: Golden in color. Light lacing. Taste: Wish pumpkin flavor was more predominant. Cocoa flavor more adds to the smell than flavor. Palate:Smooth Finishes smooth. Fits Jolly Pumpkins style of champagne yeast quality. Overall: Id buy a bottle.
beer_name: Jolly Pumpkin La Parcela No. 1 Pumpkin Ale

review_blob: Flight @ beer shoppe. 3oz. Aroma: Light fruit flavors, some sweetness. Appearance: Darker straw color, some lacing. Taste: Maybe some licorice? Strawberry, pear, apple. Palate: Lively carbonation. Finishes clean. Not too much of a linger. Overall: Good with some sour quality, good for someone looking for a mild sour taste. Prob wouldnt buy a bottle myself.

Flight @ beer shoppe. 3oz. Aroma:Light some citrus, champagne yeast, vanilla(?) Appearance: Pale yellow straw...lively carbonation. Taste: Citrus with some sourness. Palate: Smooth and clean with some sour bite to it. Lingers on the palate a bit. Overall: Alright, but I wouldnt buy a bottle.

Flight @ Beer Shoppe. 3oz. Aroma: Light citrus, pear flavor, almost floral like. Appearance: Champagne like, very carbonated, some lively bubbles. Taste: light bodied, pear flavors, some citrus. Palate: lively on palate, smooth, finishes clean. Overall: Pretty good light bodied beer.

(#58) 750ml bottle. Tulip glass. Time to put on PJs Ten album (8/27/91), decided to actually listen to it while writing and sipping. Appearance: Pours a pure golden straw color with little to no head...some white bubbles and lacing. Aroma: Sweet cherries, coriander, orange and lemon peel, apples, light melon aroma. The Chardonnay/Pinot Grigio aromas are there too. Taste: Light, sweet, fruity flavors. Currants and a honey taste dominate most of the flavor. It is sweet up front and then trails off, much like a white wine. Extremely drinkable. Palate: Light bodied. Really smooth. Creamy. Good amount of effervescence. Finishes real clean, no bad lingering aftertaste. Overall: Cool bottle to collect...prob wont see this ever sold again. Although I expected a more complex Alive flavor, not a bad one at all.
beer_name: Dogfish Head Pearl Jam Twenty Faithfull Ale

review_blob: (#57) [Blend #5 1-26-11] 750ml bottle bought in late 2010. Poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Golden/Amber with some haze...a nice deep color. Great white frothy head that sticks around, about a finger or two. Aroma: The roses are apparent! Along with cherries, raspberries, grapefruit, some light citrus maybe, melon, banana, and cloves. There is some spiciness floating around with the aroma. Taste: Interesting...tastes similar to a sour ale, mixed with some fruitiness. Berries, light citrus?, melon, pepper spice, honey. It has a certain tang to it...is this what roses tastes like? Palate: Med bodied...smooth, initially effervescent. It finishes really clean, but the taste seems to flatten out at the end. I wonder if aging it for as long as I did has affected it greatly. Overall: Its pretty clean and easy to drink. Not too complex but still has a flavor developed. I like it. Happy to have bought it, cool bottle too.
beer_name: Jolly Pumpkin Baudelaire Beer iO Saison

review_blob: (#56) 12oz bottle. Decided to pour it into the tulip glass for the hell of it. Appearance: Light amber in color, transparent. Not much of a head as expected. Aroma: Wheat and cereal grain.Some light skunk aroma. Somewhat similar to a Bud or Coors light. Taste: A bit of what I expected. Nothing major but can see how it is easily drinkable. Not much flavor significance to note here. Light cereal, hay, bread with a slight roasted flavor. Palate: Light bodied of course. Smooth and effervescent. Not a bad mouthfeel I suppose. Overall: Nothing special, mainly wanted to try this just from all of the hype I have heard over the years. Acquired bottle from an acquaintance in the military. Only available from the midwest to the east. Seems like it could be a good beer pong beer. Happy to have finally tried it here.

(#55) 750ml aged and bought in Dec. 2010. Tulip glass. Appearance: Light golden straw color, hazy. Good frothy white head retention and lacing. Aroma: Sweet but some spice to it. Clove, banana, melon, grape, honey, lemon, pepper. Taste: A nice spice to it, ginger comes through. There is a orange taste, but combines with the ginger to make it slightly bitter. Some honey sweetness. Palate: Light bodied. Smooth. Some carbonation but not much. Overall: Very easy to drink, no apparent alcohol taste. Great mellow beer, happy that I bought two. However, I was expecting more levels of flavor from all the ingredients used.

(#54) 22oz bottle bought in Dec 11. Poured into tulip. Appearance: Golden amber with a haze. Some initial head, white with not much lacing. Aroma: Sweet fruits. Cherries, pomegranates, grapes, peaches, pears. Rye whiskey notes hidden well in the back. Honey. Buttery. Taste: Sweet malt, then a little tartness/sourness from pomegranate. Clove, banana, and caramel flavors coming through. Palate: Med bodied. Smooth. Pretty good carbonation. Sour aftertaste lingering. Overall: Its a delicious Quad. I might buy another bottle if it came around. Glad to have tried it.

(#52) Pint from draft during Sac Beer Week at Streets of London. Appearance: Dark brown in color almost cant see through. Beige head. Aroma: Cinnamon, brown sugar, cherries. Taste: Big cinnamon flavor, some oak, figs, caramel. The more you drink, the bigger the spiciness of the chilies come through. Nice spice kick at the finish and warms your throat. Palate: Med. bodied.  Good carbonation, smooth and creamy. Finishes smooth with the chili flavors coming out. Overall: Great beer, just enough spice of the chili heat. Id drink lots more.
beer_name: New Belgium Lips of Faith - Cocoa Mole

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: (#51) 750ml bottle poured into tulip. Appearance: Dark brown/black with a dark tan frothy head...dissipates leaving nice tan lacing. Aroma: Heavy malty chocolate, coffee, butter, vanilla, roasted nuts, some slight date and alcohol aromas. Taste: Sweet. Coffee bean bitterness, heavy dark chocolate, caramel, vanilla, licorice, strong flavors reminiscent of bourbon. Palate: Med-Full bodied. Creamy and smooth with tons of carbonation. A pleasant syrup like coating develops. Finishes well with bitter coffee. Lingering buttery aftertaste. Overall: Pretty damn tasty. An ideal stout. Will consider buying again. You gotta try if you love stouts. Nice high ABV also.

#50 (Aged 2010 edition) Poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Golden hazy straw yellow with a great white frothy head. Nice lacing. Aroma: Orange, banana, grapefruit, honey, some clove spiciness, and cherries. Taste: Sweet then a spicy tang. Citrus fruits and cherries. Great balance throughout. Palate: Med bodied. Smooth, great amount of carbonation, creamy. Finishes clean, no harsh aftertaste. Overall: Delicious. Worth the try and would consider buying again for sure. A damn good special occasion brew.

(#49) Had this one aging since its release in Nov 2010. 22oz bottle poured into tulip. Appearance: Light Brown/Amber in color, somewhat hazy, some white bubbles, hardly any head. Aroma: Maple, dates, figs, caramel, chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar, boozy and very sugary. Taste: Malty boozy heaven. Big flavors of caramel and bourbon. Vanilla, roasted nuts, chocolate, coffee on finish. Reminiscent of a port and bourbon in one. Palate: Med-full bodied. Smooth and buttery. Coffee bitterness on finish and aftertaste. Good carbonation. Overall: Great brew. Has good body and great layers of flavor. Its too bad this is only a one time gig, I hope they decide to make it again. Ill most def buy more of it next time.

(#48) 750ml bottle aged since beginning of Jan 2011. Poured into tulip glass (substituted for snifter). Appearance: Dark coffee brown/black in color with a great creamy and frothy tan head. Aroma: Robust coffee, caramel, chocolate, vanilla. butter, espresso, and hazelnuts. Taste: Wow. Delicious. Abundance of roasted coffee beans and chocolate flavors as expected, toasted nuts, and caramel. Pleasant malt/hop balance. Palate: Med-Full body, very smooth, creamy, has that good porter dryness. Carbonation is pretty good as well. Finishes bitter but left me wanting to drink more. Overall: Great beer. I would/will buy this one again. Wonder if me aging it played into the taste.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: (#47) 750ml bottle poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Hazy golden yellow. Hardly any head. Aroma: Oranges, lemon, grapefruit, cereal, honey, and melon. Taste: Honey, citrus fruits, bread, and banana. Palate: Med. bodied, smooth, creamy textures, slight tang on finish. Overall: Nice and refreshing beer. Good flavors. Would buy again, wonder how good it would be on tap. Paired this beer with lemon and herb fish and peppered rice. Worked out well.

(#46) 22oz bottle poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Golden yellow with a slight haze, white foam head. Aroma: Lemon, banana, orange, coriander, grass, pepper, spicy. Taste: Sweet citrus that transforms to dry hops. Honey, cereal, pepper, clove, and grapefruit. Palate: Med. bodied. Smooth and sweet at first but gets rather bitter on finish and aftertaste. Overall: Its alright, a little too far on the bitter scale for my taste though. I previously tried this on draft last summer and I remember the taste being more enjoyable for me. Interesting to see what No. 3 will be.

(#45) 22oz bottle poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Dark brown/black with a tan head that dissipates. Aroma: Coffee, roasted nuts, earthy, chocolate. Taste: Dry roasted coffee, some chocolate, hazelnuts. Pretty thin and light in flavor. Some carbonation. Palate: Light bodied. Smooth, creamy, a slight bitterness. Overall: Its good for a light bodied lager. I would have liked more of something there.

beer_brewer_name: Portland Brewing Company (Pyramid - North American Breweries)
review_blob: (#44) 22oz bottle poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Golden yellow with a slight haze. White frothy head that leaves some bubbles and good lacing. Aroma: Spiciness is notable. Cloves, pepper is there, banana, lemon, pineapple, perhaps some grapes, cereal, breadiness. Taste: Peppercorns very apparent. Citrus fruits. Almost seems to mellow out on the flavor side. Palate: Light-Med bodied. Smooth. Good carbonation. Wish flavor would hit better on aftertaste. Overall: Its good. Could use more of a predominant pepper/spicy flavor throughout. Seems to lose something though...it might be contributed from me having this bottle for awhile and finally drinking it now. Id buy it again to try it more fresh. I suggest trying it for sure.

(#43) 22oz bottle poured into a tulip glass. Appearance: Hazy golden yellow with minimal head that retains some bubbles. Aroma: Sweet. Pineapple, oranges, lemon, honey, banana maybe some light grape. Taste: Sweet up front. Honey, cereal, more citrus fruits, oatmeal. Has a somewhat tangy wave of flavor through the middle. Bitter aftertaste that isnt bad, but isnt good either. Palate: Med bodied. Good amoutnt of carbonation. Its smooth but not fond of that lingering aftertaste. Overall: Its alright. I most likely wont buy it again, but nice to have tried it.

(#42) 22oz bottle. Aged myself from late 2009. Poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Dark brown/tan color from bottle. Sits black/dark brown in glass. Minimal head; dissipated quickly. Great lacing. Aroma: Molasses, caramel, dark chocolate, candied dates, vanilla. Taste: Cocoa, espresso, hazelnuts, caramel, vanilla, raisins. Some woody/smoky flavor present. Palate: Med/Full bodied. Smooth. Creamy. Good carbonation feel, not too much. Finishes with coffee tones. Overall: Delicious. I think aging this one worked well, it might be even better than when I first had it. Would prob buy again.

22oz bottle. 2010 F.H. Edition. Poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Pours a tan/light black from bottle, dark brown/black in glass. Hardly any head and no lacing. Aroma: Caramel, piney hops, sweet oats, vanilla, cereal, roasted hazelnut. Taste: Pretty sweet, chocolate, bitter hops, coffee, brown sugar, slightly "boozy." Palate: Med bodied, creamy, dry, carbonation not too high, the bitter coffee aftertaste lingers around. Overall: Its delicious, but it has more hop character than I enjoy in my Imp. Stouts. More reminiscent of a black IPA. Worth drinking, but I wouldnt necessarily buy again when looking for a stout.
beer_name: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout Hop Harvest/Fresh Hop Edition

review_blob: 750ml bottle poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Dark amber/brown in color with a white frothy head. Great lacing. Aroma: Clove, banana, honey, light citrus, pepper, floral. Taste: Sweet and tart. Slight pleasant spiciness. Caramel is there. Buttery, fruity, herbal combine nicely. Palate: Med. bodied. Lots of carbonation. Smooth finish. A little aftertaste lingering, not bad. Overall: My first try from Stillwater...delicious Belgian. Easy to drink ale. I would suggest trying, as this one was recommended to me. Great flavor.

22oz bottle. Poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Dark black/brown in color. Minimal tan head. Good lacing. Aroma: Roasted malt, toasted nuts, caramel, coffee, espresso, vanilla, chocolate. Taste: Sweet mellow malts. Roasted hazelnuts, cocoa, coffee, light licorice. Palate: Med bodied, smooth but kind of light, good carbonation, leaves a clean taste, not too bitter. Overall: Its pretty delicious. Would buy it again and will suggest it. Good flavors and easy drinking.

22oz bottle. Poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Dark brown, hazy, minimal head, white foam, good lacing. Aroma: Sweet. Honey, grapes, figs, plums, cherries. Taste: Sweet malts. Lots and lots of carbonation. A little sourness. Vanilla, brown sugar, grapes, some molasses. Some bitterness on finish. Palate: Med bodied. Smooth. Creamy. Leaves almost like a taste residue on tongue after finish. Overall: Its alright. I do like some of Abitas brews, but this isnt like my favorite. Im happy to have tried it, but better dubbels are out there. Give it a shot though, its not bad.

22oz bottle. Poured into tulip. Appearance: A nice burnt orange in color, with a very minimal head...hardly there. Some light carbonation present. Aroma: Sweet honey and citrus, maybe some grape, alcohol, vanilla, light caramel. Taste: Woah...a really sweet taste. A bit more sweet than I was expecting, this reminds me of a Muscat or a Riesling wine. It is rather smooth and the carbonation seems to add to it. Sweet honey, orange, and pear is there. Palate: Light-Semi Med. bodied. Although smooth, it kind of does have a syrup like quality to it. The taste lingers for a bit but doesnt end bad. Overall: Eh, I could have passed on this one, but I guess now I can say Ive had a Prickly Pear brew. The mead style isnt too far off from what this one is like.
beer_name: Widmer Brothers Reserve Prickly Pear Braggot

review_blob: 24oz bottle (2010 bottling) poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Pours a hazy, straw amber color with a nice, fluffy white head (good lacing). Aroma: Bold hops right up front as expected. Citrus, pine, grapefruit, light caramel. Taste: Bitter but smooth hops at first, mellow malt, then a pleasant hop taste again. Citrus fruits (lemon & oranges), grass, light vanilla, some roasted nuttiness. Palate: Med bodied. Smooth, not overpowering like most IPAs out there. Does have that weed aftertaste, done nicely. Overall: Its a great IPA, happy to have tried it, prob wouldnt buy again, but only because Im not huge on the IPA style.

22oz bottle. Poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Very dark black with a beige head, has some good froth to it. Aroma: Sweet malts, dark chocolate, caramel, vanilla, some light orange, roasted coffee & nuts. Taste: Light malt flavor, dominant orange citrus flavor but not too much, chocolate, cream...small hint of hop flavor in there also. Palate: Light bodied, fizzy, very carbonated MF, finishes smooth, roasted nuts lingering aftertaste. Overall: Pretty damn good. Kinda reminds me of those dark chocolate orange candies that you whack on the counter before eating. Too bad its not an all the time Giants beer. Delicious! Decided to drink this on the last day of the 2011 season. SF GIANTS!!!

12oz bottle from brewery rep. Poured into tulip. Appearance: Pours a hazy golden amber color. White froth dissipates leaving minimal head. Aroma: Pine, sweet hops, honey, pineapple, banana, citrus. Taste: Sour/bitter hops, malt character comes through right after, citrus fruits. Palate: Light-Med bodied, dry, leaves lingering bitter hop aftertaste. Overall: Its alright for me. Since Im not a fan of every IPA, this is one of those I wouldnt have again.

12oz bottle from friend. Poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Pours a hazy light amber color. Initial rocky white head that dissipates with good lacing. Aroma: Sweet pine notes, grapefruit, citrus, some oak, brandy, some molasses. Taste: Sweet malts mixed deliciously with hop bitterness. Grass. Pine. Hops not overwhelming, mellowed out by oak. Molasses, oak. Palate: Med-Full bodied, velvet smoothness, nice finish, no lingering bitterness. Another great one from DFH, try this one if you find it. Im usually not a fan of IPAs, but this one is great.

750 ml bottle. Bought in the Spring 11 at Nugget. Appearance: Pours semi-hazy light auburn color. An initial frothy white head, that dissipates to excellent lacing. Aroma: Sweet cherries, grapes, peaches, pear, slight alcohol, oranges, lemons, Pinot Noir is there. Taste: A malty sweetness. Cherries, citrus fruits in aroma, honey, vanilla, light caramel, good amount of oak, a hint of booze, some sourness and leaves a nice tang on the finish. Palate: Med bodied. Very smooth and drinkable. Heavy carbonation that is equally pleasant. Tart on the finish, but doesnt take away from the flavor, only adds more complexity. Overall: A really delicious beer! Its what I expected from DFH and even a little more. Would for sure buy and drink again. Try this if you have the chance. Would have let it age longer, but I had it in my beer fridge since I could only buy it chilled.      --(32nd Rating)--

22oz bottle (bottled on 06-25-09) poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Golden yellow in color with lively carbonation. Frothy white head with good lacing. Aroma: Grassy hops, pine, cereal, grapefruit, orange, lemon, hay, and bananas. Taste: Sweet citrus fruits at first then hoppiness comes forward. Hop spiciness. Fizzy. Palate: Light bodied. Dry. Smooth finish but bitter. A good Belgian style ale...I previously had this before and think I remember a different taste, could be from the age, but not sure. Have more in supply, interesting to see if there will be change next time I crack a bottle.
beer_name: New Belgium Lips of Faith - Le Fleur Misseur?

review_blob: 12oz can poured into tulip glass. Pours light tan/orange out of can and sits in glass a hazy brown/dark amber color. A little white foam and with some white lacing. Aroma: Molasses, brown sugar, vanilla, dates, cherries, bananas, chocolate, nutmeg. Taste: Sweet cinnamon, fruity, raisins, toffee. As already said, the apparent alcohol gets stronger to the finish but not overpowering. Palate: Med bodied, smooth, good carbonation, great finish...leaves you wanting more. An excellent one from 21A. I enjoy the fact that it comes from a can like their others, it doesnt take away from the flavor. Delicious....a def re-buy for sure.

22oz bottle poured into a Belgian lambic flute. Appearance: Pours a hazy amber/brown in glass. Not much of a head, was white and soon dissipated...the flute could have something to do with it. Aroma: Not surprising, the sweetness of grape juice right off the start. Pear, pineapple, cherries, oranges, light molasses. Taste: Sweet grape taste...flat, not much carbonation at all. Could have waited too long to drink? The taste seems way more toned down than the aroma. Palate: Smooth, light-med bodied, some fizzy feel. Overall: Its good but I expected a lot more. Curious to know if the taste is related to the age. Not bad at all, but I prefer the previous Rejewvenator years a lot more.

330ml bottle gifted from distributor rep. Tulip glass. Pours dark brown in color, looking fairly thin. Sits with a nice dark caramel head which does fade away. Very dark brown/black in glass. Aroma: Brown sugar, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, grain alcohol (of course), whisky very apparent, molasses, dates, honey. Very sweet aromas mixed with a strong whisky presence. Taste: Woah. I literally said out loud as soon as the first sip. Great thing I love whisky...and scotch especially. Very sweet malts right off the bat, black coffee, vanilla, molasses, Springbank taste is most def all over the place, hefty chocolate notes on finish, roasted nuts (hazelnuts?). Hardly any carbonation. Palate: Very smooth, creamy, thin feel, finishes really well, that slight pleasant whisky burn also there. An amazing strong stout and an instant favorite. Not for the weak. Taste and smell will hit you like Chuck Norris (or Sean Connery?) on a sunny day...if youre not prepared. Would buy if I find it somewhere. Side note: The flavors develop more depth the longer you drink it. I drank it at room temperature, just as the bottle says. I highly suggest you do the same. (Rating No. 28)

11.2oz btl from distributor. Batch - 467 BBD 07/01/11. Appearance: Pours a hazy golden color with a frothy white head and sitting a bit cloudy. Aroma: Hops of course more than anything. Citrus, grapefruit, light hay, notes of passionfruit, kiwi, cherry and strawberries is for sure there. Taste: Pleasantly surprising, a sweetness at first at first taste, the fruitiness happening strong, a light hop roastiness, bitters out hard on the finish, strong aftertaste of lingering hops. Palate: A good amount of carbonation, smooth, light-med bodied. Im not one for these hop forward beers, but this one has my vote of tastiness. Not sure how the flavors have changed the taste in the new recipe, but happy to know Ive tried the original 6%. I would maybe consider getting and/or recommending if I could still find this version.

12oz bottle poured into tulip glass. Appearance: Pours golden yellow and sits in glass an amber/dark orange. Lively carbonation, white foam quickly dissipates. Aroma: Sweet honey is mostly apparent, light citrus, basil is subtle with other herbal notes, lightly floral. Taste: Sweet honey hitting first, quickly mellowing out, some lemon/orange citrus flavors, a nice bitterness, herbal taste of basil really comes out towards finish. Palate: Plays like a medium bodied beer, very fizzy, smooth, leaves a pleasant, slightly spiced aftertaste. This was an interesting beer, after reading some of the ratings, I started to become more intrigued. What they did with the basil is pretty unique...I unintentionally tried this beer after eating a good pasta meal, and it meshed oddly well with the flavors I had (probably would have even gone better if I just ate a pesto sauce). I wouldnt buy this one frequently even if it wasnt seasonal, but I would def drink it again...happy to have tried it.

22oz. bottle poured into tulip glass. Dark tan/brown while pouring, sits dark black in glass with a nice frothy brown head. Aroma: Chocolate malts, roasted coffee beans, vanilla, caramel, brown sugar, and molasses. Taste: Pleasantly sweet right from the start, oak chips, black coffee, vanilla and dark chocolate. The sweetness is very smooth and not overpowering...it seems to give the hint of sweet at first, then that quick soft bitterness from coffee, before going to a sweet chocolate. Palate: Very lively carbonation with every sip, smooth and doesnt "harsh" out. Lingering sweetness on the finish of that mellows out and makes you want more. A very delicious porter, I will/would suggest this one...well worth a try. I most likely will be buying this one again in the near future.

12oz. bottle from distributor rep, poured into tulip glass. Pours yellow straw in color with a white somewhat bubbly head. Sits in glass a hazy light brown/tan color. Aroma: Big floral hops, citrus, lightly toasted. Taste: Lightly sweet at first for a short time, soon to be balanced by the hops, then finishes quite bitter. Cereal, oats, lemon, and grapefruit. Palate: Big carbonation mouth feel but smooth, heavy bitter aftertaste on finish. A pretty good amber...I would suggest it for those looking for one, but not really for me...a bit too hoppy for my taste.

22oz. bottle poured into tulip glass. Pours a light golden straw color and has a white minimal head. Aromas highly of cereal, some hay and light citrus. A very light bodied beer of course, but big on bitterness and carbonation...fizziness takes over the palate basically. Finish is bitter and very dry. Im a fan of Anchor but this isnt up there at all for their best...just the steam beer alone is way a better choice. Cool bottle but I wouldnt buy it again.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: 12.7 oz bottle poured into tulip. Pours an amber tan color out of bottle with a lively beige frothy head...sits a dark brown color (cant see through) when in the glass. Aroma is very sour of course with the abundance of cherries. Oak, caramel, vanilla, and berries on the nose also. The taste is an amazing sour experience! Sweet cherries at the start and quickly gets more sour...flavors of cherries/berries mixed slightly mixed with oak. It sits on the palate pretty lightly, nicely fizzy and the finish stays around for the right amount of time before fading away. One of the best sours I have had so far...I bought it based on its reputation and it was well worth it. You need to try this if youre thinking about it...Id highly recommend it to the sour fans.

12oz. bottle poured into tulip glass. Pours a dark brown with a very minimal  tan head. Aromas of sweet chocolate, milk, roasted coffee, hazelnuts, and a slight woodsy note. A lighter taste of chocolate than the smell. Carbonation is very effervescent, light bodied. I was expecting and wanting a bigger chocolate experience. A good beer for what it is, wouldnt necessarily buy again, but would suggest it for a first time.

22oz bottle of "Black Magic Stout" (it was this before the name change to "Voodoo") from distributor rep. Poured into tulip glass. Dark brown/black with a frothy tan colored head. Aroma is deliciously malt based with roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate, and oatmeal. Taste is sweet at start and slightly trails into bitterness. Black coffee flavors on the finish. Sits easily on the palate with a very thin creamy body. I might prefer a thicker stout. A pretty good "American" style, not too sure how the now "Voodoo" differs, but this is a tasty version not really to be found.
beer_name: Left Coast Voo Doo American Stout

review_blob: 12oz btl poured into tulip glass. Dark copper brown in color with minimal tan head. Aromas of chocolate, caramel, vanilla, sweet dates, brown sugar and a slight woodsy smell as expected...grain alcohol smell really apparent. Sweetness at first then goes into way more complexity. Obviously, not your typical brown ale...really shouldnt be classified as one. A great beer if youre looking for a strong ale for a quick effect...Not really a beer to drink multiples of at one time.

12oz. bottle sample from brewery rep. Poured into tulip glass. Pours a deep dark brown/black with a tan head which dissipated quickly. Aroma has doughy sweet malts, coffee, molasses, chocolate, and hazelnuts...roasty and toasty! Taste has that great sweetness in oatmeal stouts...more complexity arrives as you drink. A nice mellow smokiness is present which balances well with the roasted dark coffee feel. A great suggestion for a one beer sitting and even more.
beer_name: Anderson Valley Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: 500ml bottle sample from distributor rep. Pours a golden tan color from bottle and dark brown in glass. Produces a thick frothy white head and lively carbonation. Immediate aromas of bananas and clove with the faintness of chocolate in the background. Pleasant taste of the bananas and some citrus accompanying the fizziness...a delicious amount of roasted sweetness. A great German beer...would/will recommend to dark wheat fans...if youre thinking about getting it, its worth the try.

Blend #11 Bottled 12-14-10...750ml bottle bought from Co-Op here in town. Poured into tulip glass. Pours an amber brown color with a very lively frothy tan head. Aroma is a sour one with citrus hovering about...some spiciness from the cinnamon...light banana, chocolate, toasty notes as well. Taste is heavy on the sour and mellows out to reveal a hint of that cocoa flavor. Abundant carbonation all over...could see how the sourness might weigh a palate down. This beer drinks more like a saison to me...Well not really what I expected from this one, not disappointed, but not ecstatic about it either. I prob wont buy it again since Ive had it now. Great buy for the sour lovers though, I just expected and wanted more of that "cacao" taste.

12oz. btl bought from Nugget Market. Poured into tall tulip glass. Pours a dark brown/black with a tan colored head. Some carbonation still apparent after dissapation. Aroma is heavy with coffee, toffee, molasses and chocolate. Taste first starts off with the subtle bitterness that coffee endures. Well balanced sweetness met with pleasant bitterness. Smooth and creamy on the palate, aftertaste of roasted malts and coffee beans. I would def buy this again when able to, a quality beer that comes in 6pk form.
